characters.name: Teddy
facts: Origin: Comes from a recessive gene – both parents must carry the black gene.
Genetics: Entirely black from head to tail.
Line of Work: Highly sought after for personal protection and K9 work due to their intimidating look.
Fun Fact: They are NOT more aggressive than other GSDs – it’s all about training!

characters.name: Gretchen
facts: Origin: A mix of gray and black pigmentation.
Genetics: Black saddle or solid black with gray markings.
Line of Work: More common in working lines.
Fun Fact: These dogs can look very similar to blue or silver GSDs, but their genetics are different!

characters.name: Rocky
facts: Origin: A variation of the Black & Tan gene, where the tan is diluted to a silver shade.
Genetics: Black saddle with silver legs, face, and chest.
Line of Work: Found in both working and show lines, but more common in show breeding.
Fun Fact: Their silver fur gives them a majestic and almost mystical appearance!

characters.name: Wolfgang
facts: Origin: European show-line breeding programs.
Genetics: Deep reddish-brown replaces the tan areas.
Line of Work: Primarily seen in show lines due to their striking appearance.
Fun Fact: Some say their coat gives them a royal look!

characters.name: Jaeger
facts: Origin: A dominant gene variation similar to sable but with a cooler tone.
Genetics: Often looks like a mix of silver and sable.
Line of Work: Common in working and military lines due to their strong build and high drive.
Fun Fact: Gray GSDs are sometimes mistaken for wolf hybrids!

characters.name: Titan
facts: Origin: Bred from early herding GSD lines in Germany & Switzerland.
Genetics: Caused by a recessive gene but is NOT albino.
Line of Work: Popular as therapy dogs and family companions.
Fun Fact: White GSDs were once banned from the breed standard in Germany!

characters.name: Guardian
facts: Origin: Comes from a dilution of the black and tan gene.
Genetics: Light grayish-silver replaces traditional tan markings.
Line of Work: Found in both working and show lines.
Fun Fact: Silver GSDs were once highly sought after for their unique appearance in law enforcement.

characters.name: Blitz
facts: Origin: Comes from a rare dilution gene that affects pigmentation.
Genetics: Similar to black GSDs, but the blue gene dilutes the coat color.
Line of Work: More common in companion and show lines.
Fun Fact: Some kennel clubs still consider this a fault, but many owners love them!

characters.name: Nibbles
facts: Origin: Comes from a rare dilution gene that affects pigmentation.
Genetics: Similar to black GSDs, but the blue gene dilutes the coat color.
Line of Work: More common in companion and show lines.
Fun Fact: Some kennel clubs still consider this a fault, but many owners love them!

characters.name: Coco
facts: Origin: Result of a spontaneous genetic mutation.
Genetics: NOT mixed – still a purebred GSD!
Line of Work: Primarily companion dogs.
Fun Fact: First Panda GSD, Franka von Phenom, was discovered in 2000!

characters.name: Peanut
facts: Origin: The first GSDs, including the breed's founder, Horand von Grafrath, were sable.
Genetics: Agouti pattern – each hair has multiple shades.
Line of Work: Common in working lines (military, search & rescue).
Fun Fact: Their coat keeps changing shades even into adulthood!

characters.name: Duke
facts: Origin: A variation of the Black & Tan gene but with much more black.
Genetics: The tan markings are minimal (usually on the legs and underbelly).
Line of Work: Common in working lines (police, military, protection).
Fun Fact: Some bi-color GSDs are mistaken for solid black because their tan markings are so small!

characters.name: Rex
facts: Origin: Caused by a genetic mutation that results in a complete lack of pigmentation.
Genetics: True albinos have pink noses, light-colored eyes, and white fur.
Line of Work: Not recognized in most kennel clubs due to health concerns.
Fun Fact: Albino GSDs are often more sensitive to sunlight and may have vision issues.

characters.name: Valor
facts: Origin: A mix of liver and blue dilution genes.
Genetics: No black pigment in fur, nose, or eyes—coat appears fawn, silvery-lavender, or lilac.
Line of Work: Primarily in pet homes and not common in working lines.
Fun Fact: Isabella-colored GSDs often have light-colored eyes and noses, making them stand out!

characters.name: jimmy
facts: Origin: The most recognizable GSD color, developed through selective breeding.
Genetics: Dominant black saddle pattern with tan legs and face.
Line of Work: Commonly used in police work, military, and service roles.
Fun Fact: Puppies are often born darker and lighten as they mature!
